reference: Krarup, J. and Pruzan, P.M. "The simple plant location problem: Survey and synthesis." European Journal of Operational Research, 12(1), 36-81 (1983)
math_formula:
### Mathematical Model
Suppose we have:
- Set of facilities J = {1,...,n}
- Set of customers I = {1,...,m}
- f_j: Fixed cost of opening facility j
- c_{ij}: Cost of serving customer i from facility j
- d_i: Demand of customer i
- K_j: Capacity of facility j
- y_j: Binary variable indicating if facility j is open
- x_{ij}: Amount shipped from facility j to customer i
$$
\begin{aligned}
&\text{Minimize} && \sum_{j \in J} f_j y_j + \sum_{i \in I}\sum_{j \in J} c_{ij} x_{ij} \\
&\text{Subject to} && \sum_{j \in J} x_{ij} = d_i && \forall i \in I \\
& && x_{ij} \leq d_i y_j && \forall i \in I, j \in J \\
& && \sum_{i \in I} x_{ij} \leq K_j y_j && \forall j \in J \\
& && y_j \in \{0,1\} && \forall j \in J \\
& && x_{ij} \geq 0 && \forall i \in I, j \in J
\end{aligned}
$$
natural_language_example:
A retail company needs to decide where to locate distribution centers to serve its stores. They have:

Potential distribution centers:
* Location A: capacity 1000 units, setup cost $100,000
* Location B: capacity 800 units, setup cost $80,000
* Location C: capacity 1200 units, setup cost $120,000

Stores to be served:
* Store 1: demands 300 units, shipping cost varies by distribution center
* Store 2: demands 400 units, shipping cost varies by distribution center
* Store 3: demands 500 units, shipping cost varies by distribution center

The goal is to determine which distribution centers to open and how to allocate store demands to minimize total costs (setup + shipping) while respecting capacity limits of each distribution center. Each store's demand must be fully met.
